> [[ Underground: Averron City // Neutral Territory // PVP Enabled ]]

"Are you heading back?" You ask, staring at the Technician before you. You've been conscious to keep your distance.

"Negative. I'm overdue on my rounds. Rogue nameless farm monsters and players, and I farm them. It keeps their spirits low and my cred-chip fat, especially when they show up with something shiny. You should try it sometime." He gives a devilish grin, laughing for a bit. "I think you and I are a lot alike. If you'd fancy, you might stop by my workshop on the north end of town when I'm online, mm?"

Your UI pings.

> [[ Contact Request: Smith ]]

“'l'll think about it.” You respond, and fiddle with the Unique Identifier's interface for a moment before figuring out how to access your Contacts. You accept, and the Technician—Smith—is added to the empty list, a picture of his face accompanying his name. “Thanks for the help.”

“You're very welcome.” He nods, then stalks toward the opposite cave entrance. “Bye, now.”

You follow his instructions, and make your way towards Averron City proper. Footsteps echo through the tunnels around you; you maneuver carefully through caves lit by luminescent stone outcroppings. Nearby, a waterfall pours from a small rift in the ceiling, rolling gently off rocks and running through a gap into the foggy abyss below. Faintly glowing mushrooms grow in earthen patches in the corners of covered tunnels and caves. It grows cold. You feel uneasy, like something could be watching you from the darkness, and decide to pick up your pace.

> [[ 1/2 ]]
name: BSO
subject: [[ Broken Sky Online Quest - Session 2 ]]

comment:
>>37686014

> [[ Underground: Averron City – Central District // Neutral Territory // PVP Enabled ]]

The header appears as you enter the city, and a welcoming chime indicates you've gained a level. Discovery EXP, most likely. You'll check your UI when you get a spare moment.

“Welcome.” There's a pike-wielding man at the pillars that mark the city entrance, with a UI about his waist—a player. “New arrival?”

You nod. Beyond the entrance, you can see lanterns strung between the metal buildings flanking the sidewalks, and hear the chatter of people on the streets. There's a lot of players, more than you can count, and you can see more in the windows of houses and standing over the tables of market stalls.

Behind you, a few other players are stumbling toward the city. Some of look about as lost as you do, obviously new; you wonder if they had a welcome wagon as warm as yours. Among the group, you spy a few nameless; your hand eases around the hilt of your sword, still warm from earlier use. “This is Averron, huh? Anything I should know before I go in?”

“Nothing you won't find out before long. The market square is on that side of town, and player housing is to the north, if you can afford it.” He leans back, sitting on a pile of wooden crates. “We use the tavern as sort of a quest hub, if you're ever at a loss of things to do; mostly, everyone's trying to get to the surface, but there's plenty of stuff that can help further below. I'd suggest joining a guild, or finding a party. Some of the top ones so far are recruiting.”

> “A guild? Any suggestions?”
> “Are the nameless a problem here?”
> “What's down below?”
> “Are there NPCs? Where does the money for housing go?”
> “Why do you do this?”
> “Thanks. Nice meeting you.” Proceed into Averron City.
> Other.

comment:
>>37686056

“Guild, huh?” You ask. “Got any suggestions?”

“Everyone is still basically new to the game, so there's a lot of people jumping on the bandwagon. I don't get it, myself—it takes quite a few creds to start a guild, and most of 'em are going to fizzle out soon. You can't start one without five charter members, and the majority of the ones running around don't have more than eight total.” He shrugs. “There's no real leadership. Players die, there's conflicts of interest. Everyone wants to get their names out, but nothing gets done?”

“Which ones are the largest?” You ask. The group of newbies behind you is starting to crowd a little ways back, listening intently.

“The alliance surrounding Averron City is made up of three guilds. To my understanding, Disposable Heroes is leading by numbers. I'm pretty sure the name was supposed to be a joke, but so far they've been pretty good at galvanizing suicidal charges toward a unified purpose. Their officers are pretty chill, though—you'll probably run into Andor, who's sort of a personality around town. You won't get that tight-knit feeling with them, but if you join up, you'll never have a hard time finding a party.”

He continues. “Right behind them is the Writ Keepers, but they're mostly crafters and Artificers. I've heard they're really into roleplaying—moreso than everyone else, anyway, cause it's kind of hard not to roleplay in a game like this. The Crimson Guardians are in third. They've got some of the highest level players in the game so far, and they usually keep to themselves and party privately; I've been told they actually have an application process! Their leader handles all of their negotiations, and she is a /notorious/ hardass. There's a lot of smaller guilds that are pretty friendly, too. You might like that. I'd check the tavern for recruiters, or try and start your own if you think you've got the sway.”

comment:
>>37687960

“I see. What about the nameless?” A bit of nervous shuffling from behind you; you're still gripping your weapon, ready to lash out with a spinning strike. “Are they a problem here?”

“We keep it under control. Members of the alliance ensure that this territory stays neutral, and that there's no fighting inside the city. There's some sizeable guilds that aren't part of the alliance, though; Freakshow is getting bigger every minute. Most of their recruits are pissed off nameless, and there's accusations of them just being an organized PK guild. The rest of the Averron Guard keeps a good handle on the place, but I'd be careful.” He folds his arms, and looks at the group over your shoulder. “That means all of you. Don't wander about the warehouse district alone. Averron isn't that big of a city, but it's still easy to get lost. Got that?”

“Mhm. Do the guilds have halls? What about player housing—you said it's expensive, right? Where does the money go?” You ask.

“Guild Halls are near the housing district. Everything over there is a safe haven of sorts. You can't bust into houses uninvited, and PVP is disabled inside; it's only like that in houses and dungeons, that we've seen so far.” He says. “If one of the guilds took this territory, they'd reap all the rent from housing and decide how high the tax is; as it is now, they've set up an agreement to split it between themselves and put it towards the effort to reach the surface.”

“My ass.” A roguish character pipes up from behind you. He's got a hooded cloak, leather gauntlets, and boots of some sort of reptile's skin; he's slouched a bit, and his features are softly carved, a bit feminine. “Like they're not skimming half off the top? Have you /seen/ the Guardians' leader?”

“We've no reason to disbelieve them.” The guardsman responds. “And as a member of the Averron Guard, I've a personal responsibility to trust the current ruling powers.”

comment:
>>37688031

“So, are there NPCs?” You ask.

“Few. You'll recognize them, as they're humanoid, but not human.” The guardsman nods. “They handle all of the activities that are true cred-sinks, like starting guilds and purchasing food and starter gear. There's also some quest-givers; all the NPCs seem killable, but we're abiding by a policy not to. They've got enormous HP totals, and we haven't determined whether or not they're a renewable resource.”

“I see. What's down below?” You ask. “Dungeons?”

“Something like that.” He says. “I've been down once or twice—there's cave systems populated with monsters, as well as a bunch of lost city, temple-esque stuff. The Writ Keepers have a thread up on one of the message boards theorizing that all of this is a lower stratum, a world that sank from up above, but there's no way to know without exploring more down there. Dont go too deep alone.”

> [[ 3/4 ]]

comment:
>>37688096

“Alright, then. One more thing. The Averron Guard is a guild, then—and you just guard this city? Why's that?” You ask. “Aren't there better things to do than sit here?”

“Mm, I guess. But it's relaxing, and the alliance members pay us well. This game is amazing, no matter what you're doing. Everything here feels real enough to mean something. And it's good experience, when a nameless goes rogue or a monster strays too close to the town.” He responds, then laughs. “That all the questions?”

“Yeah, sorry. Just trying to get a handle on the state of things. It's been nice meeting you.” You nod. “Thanks for the help.”

“No problem! One of us will be here if you need anything.” He waves you off, and you proceed into Averron. You pass under lanterns, and into the city streets; players wave you and other newcomers toward market stalls, boasting weapons and armor, bows and arrows. There's a fountain in the center of the city with a beautiful-looking statue, and plenty of people are crowding around it.

“Man, don't you just hate those guys?” The hooded character from a moment ago deliberately runs to your side to catch up to you. “This is a fuckin' game! We should be able to do whatever we want! Right?”

“I just started. Having a blast so far.” You say. “What was the dungeon like?”

“It was a branch of the ruins down below. They're pretty expanse; it was a close fight, but we managed to beat a boss. My party was great, too.” He smiles. “There was this girl, Circe. Total cutie—real scrapper. We split on the way up, but I'm really hoping to bump into her again in town.”

“Mm...” You grimace a bit. He seems so excited, you're not sure you have the heart to tell him. “That's great. I'll have to check it out myself soon.”

“You're heading to the right place, then. Looking for a party, or a guild?” He chuckles.

“Don't know. Little of both.” As you pass through the double-doors, the dark atmosphere gives way to a surprisingly home-like environment. There's quiet chatter from all about, though it's not as loud as it was outside. The place has a sort-of fantasy flair; there's a traditional bulletin board, and it looks like there's a few people seated at tables around the place, posting on the local message boards or making contact calls via UI.

There's a few shady types, posted up in the corners of the place: the usual fare. There's an NPC bartender—a raccoon-esque humanoid in studded leather—selling drinks from behind the counter, while a female character with long hair and maxed bust size is playing the role of tavern wench. A few people are investigating the bulletin board; there's a ragtag group at a nearby table, and a nearby girl in a form-fitting outfit appears to be explaining something to a small crowd.

“Yo, check it.” Your companion elbows you in the side, pointing to a heavily-armored lance wielder at the bar; he's wearing a tabard with a red insignia. “Guardian.”

What will you do?

“I want to talk to that guy in a minute.” You respond to the kid. “Don't ruin it for me, alright?”

“No promises!” He laughs and runs off, bounding into the tavern and inserting himself into the middle of a crowd of strangers. You groan audibly, then make your way over to the girl. She's leaned up against the wall, a pair of goggles around her neck, and seems to be in a bit of a trance, thinking carefully about her words and pausing occasionally to sigh wistfully.

“Hence, we believe that the ruins beneath are part of an old city that was once on the surface of Sylvetica.” She says. “But it's difficult to believe with the structures of these caves the way they are. True, we've mined and excavated much of this place already—but that's only expounded on existing structure. There's no way all of these caves could be natural, the way the bridges have been built.”

“Or, it could, if a boon from the Celestials counts.” A robed man adjacent to her chimes in—you notice that the rest of the group isn't contributing, so much as listening intently. “We can't discount the religion of the old Sylveticans, and the Materialization Altar in the town square proves that those gods are very real, and are very willing to cause tangible effects in our world.”

“Only one Celestial Artifact has been created in Averron, though.” The girl responds. “Two, if you count the city itself.”

“Is that not enough?”

“Something like that.” You cut her a sly look. “We'll say I'm a bit overwhelmed and leave it at that.”

“Mm...” She nods. “Fair enough.”

“My apologies on her behalf.” The robed man smiles at you. His avatar is greying, but his posture stout and somewhat commanding; there's a strange sort of reality to him that you didn't get even from Smith. “She makes a habit of putting others on the spot. I think she enjoys it.”

“It's alright.” You respond, this conversation now taking a backseat to the bulletin board adjacent to you. “I really don't mind.”

There's a few groups looking for members that are meeting around the city right now; a few in and around the tavern, while others choosing the city square or player houses as rendezvous points. Some of them are simply looking for additional security while hunting monsters; others are planning on going a little bit lower to the deep caves and ruins below. There's also a number of individual advertisements; a few people looking for skilled Technicians and Artificers, and others looking for additional charter members for their guilds. Maybe you could get in on something new!

> [[ 1/2 ]]

“Maybe they were deemed incapable.” You say.

“Uhm, what?” The girl cocks an eyebrow, and for a second, you'd swear she was about to break character.

“You know, by the, uh, Celestials.” You continue. “Forgive me if I'm presuming too much, but the Nameless I've encountered thus far all seem to have failed at some task.”

“Yes,” The greying man nods. “Error in judgment, or incompetence in battle, with death as the natural consequence. In death, you are denied your Unique Identifier. Of the things that separate us from them, we believe that is the most important.”

“Then, do you think the Celestials want only the most capable to reach the surface?” You ask—it's stupid, but you're kind of getting into this.

“My.” The girl smiles. “Where'd all of this come from?”

“I dunno. I just wanted to ask a question without interrupting.” You grin, and the crowd sighs. “You said there was a Celestial Artifact in Averron, correct? Do you guys know anything about it?”

“I've seen it.” A swordsman in the crowd responds, raising a hand. “Though, not used. It belongs to Liza, the leader of the Crimson Guardians. It's part of her armor, apparently—we don't know the details of how many Gems it cost to make and how many have been put into it altogether, but word is her guild is devoting a lot of resources to upgrading it with artifice, technology, and more Gems.”

“As well as creating more Artifacts, if rumors are to be believed.” The robed man adds.

> [[ 1/2 ]]

“Nel, we'll definitely party up, but there's, uh. Something I gotta tell you.” You say, half-sitting, half-leaning on one of the sturdy tavern tables.

“Yeah? What's that?” He asks. “C'mooon, spit it out.”

“Alright, listen up. When I first started the game, I got attacked by three players. All Nameless.” You say. “And I had to kill them.”

“Hot damn, you beat three players at once in your first fight? No foolin'?” His eyes widen. “I've heard most of them were a bunch of player-killing bastards, but I'd never seen it myself. That's awesome, man! What's the deal, then?”

“I wasn't the first player they'd gone after. They'd killed others... and I think your friend Circe is...”

“No way!” He laughs, then the conversation stalls. “No way. Did I mention that she basically soloed that boss? I was on low health, so I was running like, the whole time. But she's...”

“They had a UI with that name on it.” You say. “I'm carrying it with me, as well as three others with the names of dead players. I don't know what to do with them.”

“...Oh.” Nel gives another nervous laugh, then sighs. “That's... alright, then.”

You frown—he looks pretty damn sad. “You gonna be okay?”

“Yeah, I'm fine. She was the first person I met in-game... I didn't expect.” He growls, then yells, eliciting a few stares. “Fuck this game! Top guilds acting like they control us, nameless assholes killing our fucking friends! Who EVEN can you trust? Why am I even this upset?”

comment:
>>37694273

You drag Nel out of the tavern and through the crowds of people maneuvering through the stone streets, until you arrive at the town square.

There's an enormous fountain that seems to radiate a faint light throughout the square; in the center, is a statue that appears to have been carved out of a single massive opal. It depicts a girl, no older than seven or eight, shoulder-length hair perpetually blowing in a nonexistent breeze, head upturned, sightless marble eyes forever affixed on the heavens.

She holds an ornately carved bowl in her hands, arms outstretched, and three ascending stone steps in the fountain water allow individuals to approach—just that closely. The Celestial Materialization Altar.

Nearby, there seems to be a bit of an altercation underway; a proud-looking, rapier-wielding man standing at the fountain's edge and a group of his allies appear to be standing apart from a forming group of people without Identifiers. Nameless. You notice that the swordsman and his friends wear bands on their upper arms, bearing insignias of a gilded sword and shield.

“Disposable Heroes.” Nel says. “That's Andor, their second-in-command.”

“If you're really trying to help, why haven't you done anything about reviving us 'nameless'?” A man from the disgruntled crowd shouts, eliciting cheers from those around him. “Don't tell me there isn't a way! That's bullshit, and you know it!”

“There's a reason we get our reputation for being 'player-killers'.” A man in a leather skullcap wearing a huge onyx gauntlet emerges from the crowd of Nameless. You note his tabard: black, with a crudely-drawn image of a harlequin. Freakshow? He continues. “The Nameless will attack the Identified until you start doing something about it. We outnumber you, we outskill you, and we have less to lose.”

> [[ 1/2 ]]
name: BSO

“Yield!” Andor yells, leaping forward; he draws his rapier and leaves it at the woman's throat, a barrier between the two.

“We're doing our best. As of now, the neutrality policy has ensured fairness for all players.” Andor says. He sheathes his blade, using the fountain edge as a podium. “Both the Nameless and the Identified can go forward in this world, and even work together if they like. “No one has said it isn't possible.” One of the Disposable Heroes' officers chimes in. “Which is why we're trying to get to the surface, to go forward and to cover as much ground as possible. We don't hate you. We're trying to find a way.”

You first attempt to offer one of your extra pairs of boots, but it doesn't work. The context option won't allow you to select it, and you can't even pull out the boots and manually swing them up there; it's like a strong magnetic field is acting in the opposite direction. Then, you attempt to offer one of the identifiers. You pick a random one—not Circe's.

“A Unique Identifier?” Someone in the crowd behind you shouts. “There's a goddamn PK on the Altar!”

“You!” Andor swirls around. “Explain yourself!”

“I found these,” You respond, “On the body of a rogue Nameless outside Averron. Four kills. I just started. I don't know about death, or the Nameless and Identified, or how my Identifier even works. I just know I can't carry these around anymore.”

“Well, you should know that a dead player's UI is useless.” He responds, growing a bit solemn. “There are components that look useful, but our Techs haven't been able to break them down with any tools we have available.”

“Then I'm offering them to the Altar.”

“That won't work either.” He says. “The function doesn't seem to take any items. Either it only wants Celestial Artifacts or Gems, or it just doesn't...”

You're bathed in yellow light, as Marcus's UI tumbles into the bowl. A pulse of energy ripples outward from the statue, and the dented Identifier melts into beads of gilded dust that swirl skyward, illuminating all the way to the top of the cave before vanishing.

“...work.” His eyes widen. “What the hell?”

“The UI is gone.” One of the Nameless says. “Do you think that revived its owner?”

You don't think so, but you feel a warmth within. You feel like you're doing the right thing.

The crowd is quiet.

> Other

>>37695594

“Marcus was his name.” You speak loudly. “Does anyone recognize it?”

“That was my guild leader.” One of the Nameless speaks up. There's a pause, and he wanders to the front of the group. “We went too deep and got caught off guard by the cave worms. I haven't heard from him since.”

You raise the next. “Ajax.”

There's no answer. You let it tumble into the bowl, and the same thing happens. You watch intently as the rising column of light illuminates stalactites on the cave ceiling. You think you see movement overhead.

You produce a third from your inventory. “Elanna.”

A few of the members of Disposable Heroes glance at Andor, who grits his teeth. “A recruit of mine. A friend.”

You offer it to him, arms outstretched, and he accepts, making his way up to the pedestal beside you.

“Does it work?” He asks, cautiously holding it over the bowl. “Bringing them back, is it this simple?”

“I don't think so.” You shake your head. “I mean, I'm not sure. I don't know. We'll have to wait and find out—and if we don't see them again, we'll know what it means.”

The uncertainty leaves him with a frown, so you continue. “Or, they might have given up—gotten tired of their circumstances. There's no way to know. Just do it. It feels right.”

He does, and it leaves him with a faint smile. He sighs, stepping down to the fountain lip. “Thanks.”

You produce Circe's Identifier, and prepare to dump it—then, a hand on your shoulder.

“Here.” Nel says, looking a bit more confident than before. “I've got it.”

You plant it firmly in his hands, and he grins, lowering it slowly toward the bowl so the gilded ash pours between his fingers before rising skyward. “Maybe we'll get to fight together again soon.”

> [[ 1/2 ]]
name: BSO

>>37696870

“Hey.” You say. “Did I say I wasn't interested?”

“I—oh.” She's a bit red-faced. “You're really throwing me for a loop. What, then?”

“I'm new, remember?” You suggest. “I'm just weighing my options before I decide to commit to a guild. Hell, I might even start my own. New topic: Why is your name on the Materialization Altar? It says you're the one who 'granted the Manifestation' or something.”

“Yes,” she responds, “With Liza and Andor.” You recall the other names on the Altar alongside hers.

“What's that mean?”

“Greater Altars can create environments, remember? That's called a Celestial Manifestation? This one's manifested Averron City.” She says. “Andor, Liza, and I were leading the party that made the way into this place, and when we arrived, there was an offering ready for us to make. All that was left to do was state our purpose.”

“You guys created this city, then?”

“It wasn't quite what we imagined, but it was close enough.” Ayla responds. “By the time we got there, though, we'd already realized how divergent our playstyles were. Andor was tough, but pretty laid-back overall when it came down to it. Liza was a major hardass, but she had the skills to back it up. And I think you can figure out my story. That's when we got the idea for the alliance. It would be unfair for someone to be able to contest starter territory, so we decided...”

“To start your own guilds.” It makes sense—Ayla leads the Writ Keepers, Liza leads the Crimson Guardians, and Andor is a commanding officer of Disposable Heroes. “I get it.”

“Speaking of Andor—he's been bugging me about something weird happening at the Altar earlier.” She says. “You weren't reading this when that was going on, by chance? I'd like to hear someone else's side of the story...”

You grin.
